a b s t r a c t
Pore structure is of great importance in the occurrence of shale gas. In this study, pores in shale samples from the Lower Silurian Longmaxi and Lower Cambrian Niutitang shales in Chongqing, in the Upper Yangtze Platform, South China, were examined using focused ion beameHe ion microscopy (FIBeHIM), nano-computerized tomography (nano-CT), and gas adsorption analysis. The results show that most pores in measured samples of the Niutitang shale are mineral matrix pores and have poor connectivity, including both intraparticle and interparticle pores. Organic matter pores in measured samples of the Niutitang shale are rare and have small diameters. In measured samples of the Longmaxi shale, OM poresdmostly macropores and large mesoporesdare the most abundant. The nano-CT results revealed that the abundance of OM pores led to good pore connectivity in the Longmaxi shale samples, whereas the prevalence of mineral matrix pores resulted in poor connectivity in the Niutitang shale samples. N2 and CO2 adsorption analyses showed that the mean value of microporeemesopore volumes in the Niutitang and Longmaxi shales samples are 0.0332 ml/g and 0.0261 ml/g, respectively. The mean values of microporesemesopores surface area in the Niutitang and Longmaxi shales samples are 33.84 m2/g and 32.46 m2/g, respectively. Thus, there is little difference between measured samples of the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales in terms of volume and surface area of microporesemesopores. The equal-vitrinite reflectance (equal-Ro) values of measured samples of the Longmaxi shale are lower than those of the Niutitang shale samples. Over-maturity (equal-Ro>3%) resulted in a reduction of the number of pores in organic matter, small pore size, and poor connectivity in measured samples of the Niutitang shale. Relatively low maturity (2%<equal-Ro<3%) resulted in better preservation of OM pores and good connectivity in measured samples of the Longmaxi shale. It is concluded that suitable thermal maturity is beneficial for pore development in shale, which is of great significance for shale gas exploration and development.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Shale gas exploration and development in China is currently being vigorously conducted, especially in the Upper Yangtze Platform, South China. The Longmaxi shale in Southeast Chongqing and the Niutitang shale in Northeast Chongqing are the two main

marine shale-gas-producing series in South China. Shale gas exploration and development have been actively conducted in both formations; however, development is unsatisfactory, especially for the Niutitang shale.
The Longmaxi shale in Southeast Chongqing in the Upper Yangtze Platform has produced industrial gas flow and has become a typical demonstration area for shale gas exploration and development in South China (Dai et al., 2014; Guo et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2015; Shi et al., 2015; Yan et al., 2015). However, exploration and development of the Niutitang shale in Chongqing are
unsatisfactory; for example, Niutitang shale gas production is extremely low in Northeast Chongqing. Moreover, data from existing drilling wells demonstrate that the Niutitang shale has a low volume and short duration of gas production.
Shale gas production in the Niutitang shale in South China greatly varies with location.Wan et al. (2015) studied the diffusivity and porosity anisotropy of the Niutitang shale in Hunan Province and argued that there were different amounts of dead-end pores in the Niutitang shale. Chen et al. (2015) also studied swelling of the Niutitang shale in methane in Hunan Province and concluded that the adsorption capacity in Niutitang shale displayed strong anisotropy. However, some studies have indicated that the Niutitang shale has high exploration and development potential (Tan et al., 2014a; Wang et al., 2015b; Yang et al., 2016).
Tan et al. (2014a) stated that the methane sorption capacity of the Niutitang shale is controlled by TOC content, but can be influenced by clay minerals. Xing et al. (2011) argued that the Niutitang shale in the Weixian Sag of the Dianqianbei Depression contains a potential shale gas exploration series with very large quantity of shale gas resources based on the high total organic carbon (TOC) content (3%e15%), equal vitrinite reflectance (equal-Ro) values indicating moderate maturity (1.39%e2.24%), and large area. Yang et al. (2016) concluded that the Niutitang shale has high shale gas potential with a high TOC content and large thickness in the middle of the Mayang Basin in Hunan Province.
It has been found that the Niutitang shale displays exploration and development potential in several regions in southern China (Pan et al., 2015; Cao et al., 2015; Chen et al., 2015); however, the regions differ from one another, and analysis of specific regions is required. Previous studies have demonstrated that the pore structure of the Niutitang shale in Chongqing is not clear (K ríbek et al., 2007; Wang et al., 2012; Ma et al., 2015). The Niutitang shale reservoir is characterized by very high pore structure heterogeneity, which may influence gas production (Ross and Bustin, 2009). Furthermore, the distributions of pore type, pore volume, and pore surface area in the Longmaxi shale require research, and comparison of the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales should be performed.
Shale gas primarily exists in shale pores as adsorbed gas, free gas, or a small amount of dissolved gas, and pore structure is of great importance for the storage and permeability capacity of shale gas. The pore structure, which controls the transport mechanisms and occurrence states of shale gas, can be described in terms of type, size, volume, surface area, and spatial distribution, all of which have important effects on shale gas enrichment (Curtis, 2002; Loucks and Ruppel, 2007; Loucks et al., 2009, 2012; Slatt and O'Brien, 2011). Therefore, shale pore structure and storage capacity are of great importance for shale gas occurrence and may directly affect shale gas exploration (Scherdel et al., 2010; Schmitt et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2014). Previous studies have shown that the storage capacity of a shale reservoir plays vital roles in the storage and migration of hydrocarbon gas. Determinants of shale gas storage capacity include pore type, volume, surface area, and spatial distribution of pore connectivity, all of which have important effects on enrichment of shale gas.
Loucks and Ruppel (2007) and Loucks et al. (2012) first used scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with Ar-ion polishing to observe the pore types in shale. Pore types include both mineral matrix pores and organic matter pores (OM pores) with extremely complex network structures (Loucks et al., 2009, 2012; Clarkson et al., 2013; Chen and Xiao, 2014). OM pores are intraparticle pores developed inside organic matter during the process of hydrocarbon generation from kerogens. Mineral matrix pores are pores developed between or within mineral particles, including interparticle pores (interP pores) and intraparticle pores (intraP pores). Interparticle pores, forming during the process of diagenetic
alteration and compaction, are found between particles and crystals such as siliceous minerals (quartz and feldspar), clay and carbonate minerals (calcite or dolomite). Intraparticle pores are found inside particles such as clay, pyrite and carbonate minerals (calcite or dolomite), as a result of diagenesis and dissolution (Loucks et al., 2012; Milliken et al., 2013). OM pores contain effective interconnections that are favorable for gas adsorption (Chalmers et al., 2012; Romero-Sarmiento et al., 2014; Jiao et al., 2014; Klaver et al., 2015). SEM has increasingly been adopted to study shale samples from different regions. For example, Slatt and O'Brien (2011) studied pore types in the Barnett and Woodford shales in the America, concluding that microfractures and OM pores provide storage spaces and permeability pathways for migration of natural gas molecules. Milliken et al. (2013) were the first to study OM pore systems in shale quantitatively and determined the influence of TOC content on the development of organic matter and pores. Klaver et al. (2012) used SEM technology to study the pore space morphology of the low-maturity Posidonia shale from Hils, Germany. Tian et al. (2013) studied the OM pore characteristics in the Lower Silurian Longmaxi shale in the Chuandong Thrust Fold Belt, southwest China using on field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) digital images. Jiao et al. (2014) and Wang et al. (2016a) obtained quantitative analysis of Lower Silurian Longmaxi shale pores using focused ion beamescanning electron microscope (FIB-SEM) image processing and multifractal geometry.
Pores can be divided into three types based on their diameters according to the definition provided by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC; Sing et al., 1985). Several previous studies have used indirect testing methods for quantitative characterization of pores (Clarkson et al., 2013; Tian et al., 2013), including high-pressure Hg analysis for macropores (diameter > 50.0 nm), N2 adsorption analysis for mesopores (2.0 nm < diameter < 50.0 nm), and CO2 adsorption analysis for micropores (diameter < 2.0 nm). Pathways that allow natural gas permeation primarily occur in macropores, whereas adsorption and diffusion occur in micropores and mesopores. Thus, pore structure controls the transport mechanism and occurrence state of shale gas (Slatt and O'Brien, 2011; Milliken et al., 2013; Clarkson et al., 2013).
Ross and Bustin (2009), Clarkson et al. (2013), and Schmitt et al. (2013) argued that N2 adsorption and Hg-injection capillary pressure techniques could provide a database and system parameters for the shale pore structure and storage capacity. Subsequently, Hu et al. (2015) and Chen et al. (2015) measured the distributions of mesopores and micropores in shale and analyzed the gas storage capacity for methane adsorption based on N2 and CO2 adsorption data. Pan et al. (2015) analyzed the pore structure and porosity of the Permian shale in the Lower Yangtze region, Eastern China, based on N2 and CO2 adsorption data, and concluded that the TOC content was the key factor controlling the shale gas storage capacity.
To identify the reason for the large differences in shale gas production between the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales, the pore structure and storage capacity of both shales samples were studied. In this work, we used technologies such as focused ion beameHe ion microscopy (FIB-HIM), nano-computerized tomography (nanoCT), and gas adsorption and analyzed the pore structures in the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples. We used whole-aperture analysis to obtain the pore storage capacities of both shales samples and performed a comparison. Thermal maturity is the main reason for the differences between the pore structures in measured samples of the two shales. The results demonstrate that studying the pore structures and storage capacities of the two main sets of shale reservoirs is of crucial significance for shale gas exploration and development.

sections.heading: 2. Samples and geological setting
sections.text:
The Longmaxi shale in Southeast Chongqing is an abyssal continental-shelf facies deposit of Silurian age in the Upper Yangtze Platform, South China (Fig. 1). The shale reservoir is thick and distributed over a wide area, with intermediate cover depth, high thermal maturity, high organic matter content, and high siliceous mineral content (Dai et al., 2014; Guo et al., 2014; Jiao et al., 2014; Yan et al., 2015). Tang et al. (2015) obtained TOC values of Longmaxi shale samples of 0.16%e2.32%, with mean value of 1.13%. Jiao et al. (2014) argued that the kerogen type of the Longmaxi shale is IeII and found that the shale in South China has a TOC content of 0.51%e25.73% (mean value 2.6%) and equal-Ro of 1.6%e3.0%. Tan et al. (2015) obtained equal-Ro of 2.5%e3.0% for the Longmaxi shale. This reservoir is of great importance for shale gas exploration and development in the study area.
The Niutitang shale was deposited during the early Cambrian in a marine abyssal continental-shelf setting in the Upper Yangtze Platform, South China (Fig. 1). This shale is thick and distributed over a large area, has a wide extension, deep cover depth, over thermal maturity, high organic matter content, and high siliceous mineral content (Wang et al., 2012; Zeng et al., 2013; Yang et al., 2014; Han et al., 2015; Liang et al., 2015). K ríbek et al. (2007) calculated the TOC content of the Niutitang shale from Guizhou Province to be 6.8%e10.3% and found that the TOC content of black shale can be as much as 15% in the lowermost part of the formation. Tan et al. (2015) obtained equal-Ro values of between 3.0% and 3.5% for the Niutitang shale in the Upper Yangtze region, with a high TOC content of 1.38%e13.20%. Chen et al. (2015) argued that the mean
value of TOC content in Niutitang shale samples is about 6.96% and that the shale displays a high-maturity of 2.45%. Zhu et al. (2014) studied Niutitang shale samples from Zhangjiajie, Hunan Province, and also obtained high TOC values of 4.5%e9.6%. Xing et al. (2011) studied the Niutitang shale in the Weixin Sag of the Dianqianbei Depression and detected a high TOC content (3%e15%). The Niutitang shale is also an important horizon for shale gas exploration and development in the study area.
The Niutitang and Longmaxi shales are not markedly different from each other in terms of the geochemical characteristics of their reservoirs. The TOC content of the Niutitang shale is slightly higher than that of the Longmaxi shale (K ríbek et al., 2007; Jiao et al., 2014; Tang et al., 2015; Chen et al., 2015). Tan et al. (2015) suggested that the thermalmaturity of the Longmaxi and Nititang shales are 2.5%e 3.0% and 3.0%e3.5%, respectively, indicating that the Niutitang shale is more mature than the Longmaxi shale.
All shale samples used in this study were obtained from successfully drilled wells. Eighteen shale samples from the Silurian Longmaxi shale were obtained fromwells JY1, JY4, JY6, JY7, and JY8, which are located in the FulingeJiaoshiba area of Southeastern Chongqing, South China. Thirty-three samples of Niutitang shale used in this study came fromwells CQ1, CQ2, CQ3, and CQ4, which are located in Northeastern Chongqing, South China. N2 and CO2 adsorption analyses and focused ion beameHe ion microscopy (FIBeHIM)were performed for part of the two sets shale samples to determine the pore types and structural distributions of the two shales (Table 1).

sections.heading: 3. Methodology
sections.text: Observations and experiments were performed at the China University of Petroleum (Beijing), using focused ion beameHe ion microscopy (FIB-HIM), nano-computerized tomography (nano-CT) and bymeasuring the adsorption of various gases, including N2 and CO2. Whole-aperture analysis was applied to determine the volume and surface area of microporesemesopores from the gas adsorption results.

sections.heading: 3.1. FIB-HIM
sections.text:
FIB-HIM has a resolution that is higher than that of FE-SEM and can be down to 0.5 nm (@45 kV). FIB-HIM can be used to distinguish shale micropores. We employed FIB-HIM to analyze the shale
pore type in the both shales. The instrument used was a NanoFab ORION microscope made by Carl Zeiss, Jena, Germany. HIM is capable of the ultra-high resolution necessary to identify OM pores. FIB-HIM sample preparation involves grinding and Ar-ion polishing.
The microscope has better capacity on identifying pores since helium ion beam, which can detect inner part of pores compared with electron beam, could give better prominence to morphology of pores, leading to three-dimensional features of pores in the horizontal distribution (Fig. 5). It is possible to identify organic matter and minerals in the FIB-HIM photos according to back scattering ionic contrast analysis: pores are black with threedimensional features; quartz and feldspar are black without three-dimensional feature; organic matter is dark grey; clay minerals and carbonates are light grey, which are identified by their morphology since clay minerals often distribute as flake while carbonates as block.

sections.text:
Nano-CT can be used to characterize pore networks and connectivity. We used an UltraXRM-L200 nano-CT manufactured by XRadia, USA with a photon energy of 8 keV to create 3D images with 50 nm resolution under laboratory conditions. The nano-CT equipment includes an UltraXRM-L200 stereo X-ray microscope, an Oxford microscopic sampling system and Avizo software. Nano-CT can also be used for 3D imaging of original rock, distribution determination, size measurement, and identification of nanopore and nanothroat connectivity in shale reservoirs. The LFOV model was used in this study, and the shale samples were 65 mm in diameter.

sections.heading: 3.3. Gas adsorption
sections.text:
We qualitatively characterized the pore structures in samples of both shales by N2 adsorption and CO2 adsorption experiments and determined the volume and surface area distributions of microporesemesopores.
N2 adsorptionwas mainly used to analyze the pore volumes and surface area distributions of mesopores when the relative pressure (P/P0) was between 0.01 and 1. N2 adsorption analysis was conducted using a four-station automatic surface area and porosity physical adsorption instrument (Quadrasorb-SI, Quantachrome Ins, USA). Before the experiment, the shale samples were passed through a 200-mesh sieve, after which 5 h of dehydration treatment and 24 h of vacuum degassing treatment were performed at 383.15 K. Finally, the isothermal adsorption and desorption
experiment was completed at a temperature of 77.35 K. We determined the pore sizes, volumes, and surface areas using the BarretteeJoynereeHalenda (BJH) method (Groen and P erezRamırez, 2004; Scherdel et al., 2010; Wang et al., 2015a; Xiong et al., 2015).
The micropore structure was characterized by the CO2 gas isothermal adsorption method at 273.15 K (cold water bath). Because CO2 gas can enter a pore with a diameter of 0.35 nm, the distribution of micropores can be calculated by the DensityeFunctionaleTheory (DFT) model. CO2 adsorption analysis was performed using an Autosorb-IQ-MP, manufactured by Quantachrome, USA. Before the experiment, the shale samples were passed through a 100-mesh sieve and underwent vacuum degassing for 20 h at a temperature of 383.15 K (Labani et al., 2013; Hu et al., 2015; Pan et al., 2015). We determined basic pore parameters such as surface area, aperture and pore volume.
From the results of the CO2 and N2 adsorption experiments, the distribution characteristics of the pores were obtained. The lowtemperature CO2 adsorption method is only suitable for characterization of micropores, so we also used a mixture of CO2/DFT and N2/BJH to characterize the microporeemesopores distributions. In this study, N2 adsorptionwas used to measure pores with apertures of 1.5e60 nm and CO2 adsorption was applied for pore sizes of 0.3e1.5 nm; thus, a combination of N2 and CO2 gas adsorption can be used to obtain the pore volume and surface area distributions for

sections.heading: 4.1. Pore types
sections.text:
The obtained HIM images revealed that OM pores are well developed in the Longmaxi shale samples. Initially, in macroscopic view at the 2 mm or 1 mm scale, large amounts of black banding and polygonal materials were observed (Fig. 5a, f, k). The magnification was gradually increased to a scale of 500 nm or 200 nm, at which the materials were revealed to be essentially organic matter containing large numbers of pores (Fig. 5b, c, g, l, m). Both of Longmaxi and Niutitang shale formations of Upper Yangtze Platform in the South of China are developed in deep water marine environment (Tan et al., 2014b; Chen et al., 2014; Ji et al., 2015; Xiong et al., 2015). The strong reducing environment and quiet water of deep marine environment guaranteed high organic carbon content in Longmaxi shale, providing material base for OM pores. These pores were observed to be abundant and to have large diameters. The OM pores in the Longmaxi shale samples could be classified into mesopores and macropores because of their large range of pore sizes (5e200 nm). Furthermore, small pores were found to be nested within large ones. These small pores play the role of throat, which are beneficial to better connection of OM pores (Fig. 5bee, gej, meo). It can be indicated that macropores contribute the most to pore connectivity from the HIM photos. Due to the high resolution of FIB-HIM, we can observe that there are a lot of pores with small sizes on the surface of organic matter (Fig. 5e, j, o, pet). This can increase the surface area of shale pores, which is favorable for the occurrence of adsorbed gas.
The characteristics of the Longmaxi shale samples, such as the OM pore diameters, nesting of smaller pores inside larger ones, presence of smaller pores on the surface of organic matter, and intensive degree of OM pores development, were apparent. These characteristics increase the surface area and pore connectivity of the shale and to some extent provide space for gas absorption (Milliken et al., 2013; Jiao et al., 2014).
The same device and sample preparationmethodswere used for the Niutitang shale samples as for the Longmaxi shale samples. We observed that pores were seldom developed inside the organic matter of the Niutitang shale samples. For example, therewere very few pores developed in the organic matter which were distributed within the pyrite (Fig. 6p, q, ret). OM pores were rarely observed in the Niutitang shale samples, and those that were found had small diameters. The organic matter exhibited few micropores and mesopores (5e30 nm), and these were isolated from one another with no connectivity (Fig. 6kem). Furthermore, these pores were found to have diameters smaller than those in the Longmaxi shale samples and phenomena such as smaller pores nesting inside larger ones (as were observed in the Longmaxi shale samples) were not detected. There are beneficial sedimentary environment for development of OM pores in both shale formations, but the Niutitang shale had been more deeply buried, which indicates the less amounts as well as smaller size of pores inside organic matter as a result of stronger thermal evolution (Loucks et al., 2012; Milliken et al., 2013; Tan et al., 2013).
OM pores are abundant in the Longmaxi shale samples; in contrast, the quantity of OM pores in the Niutitang shale samples is not as great as that in the Longmaxi shale samples. The pores in the Niutitang shale samples are mainly mineral matrix pores, including both intraP (Fig. 6g, hej, n, o) and interP pores (Fig. 6aef). There was relatively high siliceous minerals content as well as certain
amount of clay and carbonate minerals in the deep water marine shale, which provides material base for development of mineral matrix pores in the Niutitang shale samples. IntraP pores are mainly developed within clay and carbonate mineral particles (Fig. 6g, hej, n, o). InterP pores mostly occur between particles at contacts between carbonate minerals and siliceous minerals such as quartz and feldspar (Fig. 6aef). However, there is smaller amount of these micron-scaled interP pores than OM pores in the same view of photos. These pores are supposed to host free shale gas to some extent as well as are beneficial to percolation of shale gas (Loucks et al., 2009, 2012; Tian et al., 2013; Klaver et al., 2015; Li et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016b). IntraP pores are generally isolated within clay particles and are not connected with each other. The pore types and development in the Niutitang shale samples are not beneficial for shale gas exploration.
N2 adsorption data can produce a hysteresis loop, the shape of which can be used to deduce the geometric shapes of shale pores. IUPAC divided hysteresis loops into four types. According to the IUPAC classification of hysteresis loops, H2 loops are often associated with ink-bottle-shaped pores; H3 loops are narrow, with adsorption and desorption curves nearly parallel, reflecting slitshaped pores; and H4 loops are usually associated with narrow slit-like pores (Sing et al., 1985; Clarkson et al., 2013; Li et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2015a).
As shown in Fig. 7, the hysteresis loop of the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms of the Longmaxi shale samples is relatively large and is similar to H2 hysteresis loop; the inflection point occurs at a relative pressure of 0.4e0.5, mainly corresponding to inkbottle-shaped pores (Fig. 8a). The hysteresis loop of N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms in the Niutitang shale samples are narrow and their turning points are not obvious, similar to H3 loops (Fig. 7eeh). This result indicates that the Niutitang shale samples contain slit-like pores (Fig. 8b).
However, compared with a typical H3 loop, the Niutitang shale samples loop are narrow, with the characteristics of H4 loop (Fig. 7eeh), exhibiting obvious compound characteristics. The adsorption and desorption curves are nearly parallel, and hysteresis loop is not obvious. When the relative pressure is larger than 0.4, the adsorption and desorption curves almost overlap, indicating that narrow slit-shaped pores (Fig. 8c) are present in addition to slit-shaped pores, which are mainly carbonate and other mineral surface-dissolution pores. Based on the N2 adsorption hysteresis loop results, it was determined that the Longmaxi shale samples had better pore connectivity than the Niutitang shale samples.

sections.heading: 4.2. Pore connectivity
4.3.1. Pore volume
sections.text:
Based on the microporeemesopore size distributions obtained via N2 and CO2 adsorption, it was determined that mesopores constitute most of the pore volumes in the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples (Fig. 11 and Table 2), while their micropore volumes are significantly less than their mesopore volumes. The mean value of micropore and mesopore volumes in the Longmaxi shale samples were found to be 0.0057 ml/g and 0.0204 ml/g, respectively, comprising 21.38% and 78.62%, respectively, of the total pore volumes (Table 2). Therefore, more than 70% of micropores-mesopores volume in the Longmaxi shale samples is contained within mesopores, with the contribution of micropores being very small (Table 2).
The mean value of micropore and mesopore volumes in the Niutitang shale samples were determined to be 0.0058 ml/g and 0.0274 ml/g, respectively, comprising 16.79% and 83.21%, respectively, or the total pore volumes (Table 2). Thus, more than 80% of micropores-mesopores volume in the Niutitang shale samples is contained within the mesopores, and the contribution of
micropores is small. The mean values of micropores-mesopores volumes in the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples are 0.0261 ml/g and 0.0332 ml/g (Table 2), respectively, so we concluded that the mean value of total pore volume of the Niutitang shale samples is slightly larger than that of the Longmaxi shale samples.

sections.heading: 4.3.2. Pore surface area
sections.text: Micropores form most of the surface area of microporesemesopores in the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples, slightly more than mesopores (Fig. 11 and Table 1). The mean value of micropore and mesopore surface areas of the Longmaxi shale samples are 17.19 m2/g and 15.27 m2/g, respectively, and the proportions of the micropores-mesopores surface area are 52.13% and 47.87%, respectively. The average micropore and mesopore surface areas in the Niutitang shale samples are 17.32 m2/g and 16.52 m2/g, respectively, making up approximately 49.19% and 50.81% of the total micropores-mesopores surface area, respectively. In the Niutitang shale samples, the contribution of micropores to the micropores-mesopores surface area is larger than that of mesopores. The mean value of microporesemesopores surface areas in the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples are 32.46 m2/g and 33.84 m2/g, respectively; thus, there is little difference between the micropores-mesopores surface areas of the two shales samples.

sections.heading: 5. Discussion
sections.text:
The pore structure characteristics of the Niutitang and Longmaxi shales samples were analyzed and compared using FIB-HIM and
low-pressure N2 and CO2 adsorption experiments. Based on the pore volumes and pore surface area distributions determined using the gas adsorption method, it was concluded there is little difference between the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples in terms
of their mean value of volumes and surface areas of microporesmesopores, suggesting that the two shales samples possess similar shale gas storage capacities.
Chen et al. (2015) studied the swelling of Niutitang shale samples in terms of methane in Hunan Province and determined that the adsorption capacity of the Niutitang shale samples displayed strong anisotropy. Tan et al. (2014a) demonstrated that Niutitang shale samples had a high potential methane sorption capacity that was controlled by TOC content in the Upper Yangtze Platform, South China. The TOC content of the Niutitang shale samples is high, with mean value of 3.5%. Our study revealed that the Niutitang shale samples have a high shale gas storage capacity due to its high pore surface area.
According to analyses of the correlations between the Niutitang shale samples pore structure parameters and the TOC content (Ji et al., 2015; Cao et al., 2015; Tian et al., 2015), the pore volume and surface area of micropores and mesopores increase with increasing TOC, demonstrating that TOC is one of the most important controlling factors for shale pore structure (Milliken et al., 2013; Tan et al., 2014a; Chen et al., 2015). Hence, we can conclude that during shale diagenesis, dehydrogenation and hydrocarbon-generation reactions occur in organic matter as maturity increases, resulting in a rise in the number of OM pores and enlargement of the OM pore size.
Xing et al. (2011) argued that the Niutitang shale samples in the Weixian Sag of the Dianqianbei Depression contains a potential
shale gas exploration series with very large shale-gas resources based on high TOC content (3%e15%). Yang et al. (2016) determined that the Niutitang shale samples have a high shale gas potential with a high TOC content and large thickness in the middle of the Mayang Basin in Hunan Province. There is a high TOC content (mean value 3.5%) and high clay content (mean value 24.7%) in the Niutitang shale samples, indicating high storage capacity; however, the production of Niutitang shale gas is low.
Based on the results of the N2 and CO2 adsorption experiments, it was determined there is little difference between the micropores-mesopores structures of the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales samples. The volume and surface area of the microporesemesopores in the Longmaxi shale samples are similar to those of the Niutitang shale samples; however, based on the HIM and nano-CT results, we concluded that the Longmaxi shale samples have better connectivity than that of the Niutitang shale
samples. This difference may result from differences in the types of pores that have developed in the two shales samples.
According to the obtained HIM images, themost abundant pores in the Longmaxi shale samples are large-diameter OM pores, including macropores and mesopores (Jiao et al., 2014; Tian et al., 2015). The nano-CT images of the Longmaxi shale samples also showed that abundant macropores and mesopores with good connectivity occur in organic matter. Milliken et al. (2013) and Guo et al. (2015) argued that OM pores dominated the shale pore system and controlled the distribution of the accumulated absorbed and free gas. The large OM pores act as the main pathways connecting other large pores, leading to better connectivity in the Longmaxi shale samples than in the Niutitang shale samples. At the same time, well connectivity is beneficial to the improvement of permeability of Longmaxi shale samples, while worse connectivity is adverse to the improvement of permeability of Niutitang shale samples, which indirectly suggests the permeability of Longmaxi shale samples is greater than Niutiang shale samples (Milliken et al., 2013; Jiao et al., 2014; Chen et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016b).
The large number of OM pores has resulted in good pore connectivity in the Longmaxi shale samples (Fig. 12a), which is beneficial for the flow of gas in the shale reservoir; consequently, the
Longmaxi shale exhibits higher gas production than the Niutitang shale (Guo et al., 2015). In the Niutitang shale samples, the pores are mainly mineral matrix pores, such as intraP and interP pores; OM pores are rare and small in size, mostly being micropores and mesopores.
Wan et al. (2015) indicated that there are different amounts of dead-end pores in the Niutitang shale samples in Hunan Province. Dead-end pores are isolated in mineral matrix and are not beneficial for pore connectivity in shale. Milliken et al. (2013) and Guo et al. (2015) argued that pores developed in mineral matrix are smaller onmean value and haveworse connectivity than OM pores. Isolated pores act as storage spaces for shale gas but are not beneficial for seepage because of their poor connectivity. Therefore, the real cause of the low production of shale gas in the Niutitang shale is poor pore connectivity (Fig. 12b), which is controlled by the mineral matrix pores. However, based on the HIM images, it can be concluded that higher-quality OM pores are developed in the Longmaxi shale samples than in the Niutitang shale samples in terms of pore size, pore quantity, and development of nested pores.

(2014b) obtained that the Lower Cambrian shale deposited in restricted deep-water marine platform to marine basin environments in the Upper Yangtze Platform, whereas the Lower Silurian shale deposited in a more restrictedmarine basin environment in the Upper Yangtze Platform. These two formations shales both belonged to restricted deep-water marine platform, indicated their similar minerals composition. The levels of quartz and clay minerals of the two shales samples in this study were also similar.
The Lower Cambrian Niutitang shale has high TOC content (Xing et al., 2011; Zhu et al., 2014; Ma et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2015b): the TOC values of the Niutitang shale samples in this study are 0.24%e 7.23%, with mean value of 3.5%. A high TOC content is beneficial for the occurrence of adsorbed shale gas (Tan et al., 2014a; Wan et al., 2015; Chen et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2016). The organic matter content of the Longmaxi shale samples (mean value 3.2%) is lower than that of the Niutitang shale samples (mean value 3.5%). The TOC contents of the two shales samples are similar to each other, with mean values of more than 3% in both. Thus, these factors are not the main reasons for the differences between the shale pore structures of the two shales samples.
The thermal maturities of the two shales samples differ greatly (Xing et al., 2011; Tan et al., 2015; Chen et al., 2015; Yang et al., 2016). Equal-Ro is relatively high in the most Niutitang shale samples, between 3% and 4%, and it was found to be greater than 4% in some of the shale samples in this study. Equal-Ro is relatively lower in the Longmaxi shale samples than in the Niutitang shale samples, being between 1.9% and 3%. The thermal maturity of the Longmaxi shale samples is lower than that of the Niutitang shale samples. We expect that the thermal maturity difference is the main factor causing the difference between the pore structures of the two shales samples based on the experimental data obtained from the present study and the results of previous research. During hydrocarbon generation from organic matter, according to the model of thermal degradation of kerogen hydrocarbons (Tissot et al., 1974, 1987), the number of pores in organic matter increases with increasing thermal maturity in reservoir. However, when Ro exceeds 3%, the number of OM pores begins to decrease. This could be caused by carbonization of organic matter during over-maturity, as a result of which the OM pores become infilled or disappear (Tissot et al., 1974, 1987).
Tan et al. (2013) argued that the deepest burial depth of 6000 m with the maximum temperature of 220 C of Lower Cambrian Niutitang shale occurred during the Late Jurassic in the Upper Yangtze Platform, suggesting that this shale experienced strong compaction and thermal evolution. In this study, excessively high equal-Ro values of the Niutitang shale samples also indicated that they experienced strong thermal evolution over geological time, which caused its organic matter to become carbonated and subsequently resulted in a decrease in the number of OM pores as well as a decrease in their diameters (Milliken et al., 2013; Chen and Xiao, 2014). The burial depth of the Longmaxi shale is mostly between 2000 m and 4500 m in the Upper Yangtze Platform, with the greatest burial depth being 3000 m in the study area (Chen et al., 2014). The Lower Cambrian Niutitang shale has been deeply buried and experienced strong thermal evolution. The Lower Silurian Longmaxi shale was buried more shallowly than the Niutitang shale, indicating that the former is less thermally mature than the latter. The equal-Ro values of the Longmaxi shale samples are lower than those of the Niutitang shale samples, indicating that the organic matter in the Longmaxi shale samples is relatively less thermally mature, and large numbers of pores were preserved in organic matter (Fig. 12a). Thus, the over-maturity (equal-Ro>3%) of the Niutitang shale caused the number and diameters of pores in organic matter to decrease and the poor pore connectivity
(Fig. 12b). Over-maturity and strong thermal evolution caused a reduction in the number of pores in organic matter, small pore size, and poor pore connectivity in the Niutitang shale samples, resulting in the low gas production of the Niutitang shale. In the Longmaxi shale, however, the relatively low maturity (2%<equal-Ro<3%) and shallow burial depth were beneficial for the preservation of OM pores, so the pore connectivity is good and gas production is high. Therefore, the key to high exploration effectiveness of shale gas is suitable maturity, and over-maturity (equal-Ro>3%) of shale is not conducive to shale gas exploitation.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text:
(1) Pores in measured samples of the Longmaxi shale are mainly OM pores. Most OM pores are macropores and large mesopores. Pores aremainlymineralmatrixpores and includeboth intraparticle and interparticle pores in measured samples of the Niutitang shale, and OM pores are seldom developed. (2) Themeasured samples of the Longmaxi shale have good pore connectivity, while the measured samples of the Niutitang shale have poor connectivity. Large numbers of OM pores have resulted in the good pore connectivity in the Longmaxi shale samples. The poor pore connectivity in the Niutitang shale samples was caused by the large number of mineral matrix pores and the rarity of OM pores. (3) The mean value of micropores-mesopores volumes of measured samples of the Niutitang and Longmaxi shales are 0.0332 ml/g and 0.0261 ml/g, respectively, and their mean value of micropores-mesopores surface areas are 33.84 m2/g and 32.46 m2/g, respectively. The differences between the mean value of volumes and surface areas of microporesmesopores in measured samples of the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales are small. (4) The equal-Ro values of the Longmaxi shale samples are lower than those of the Niutitang shale samples. Over-maturity (equal-Ro>3%) caused a reduction in pore number, small pore size, and poor connectivity in the organic matter in Niutitang shale measured samples. Relatively low maturity (2%<equal-Ro<3%) resulted in large numbers of OM pores and good connectivity in measured samples of the Longmaxi shale. Suitable thermal maturity is beneficial for pore development in shale.
This study is significant for future work on analysis of pore structure in the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales in the Chongqing, the Upper Yangtze Platform. The reason for the low gas production in the Niutitang shale in the study area is poor pore connectivity. We clarified that over-maturity (equal-Ro>3%) is amain reason that led to its poor pore connectivity and low gas production in the Niutitang shale samples in the study area. In conclusion, the maturity of shale is the most important factor influencing its pore structure and gas exploration potential.

In this study, pores in shale samples from the Lower Silurian Longmaxi and Lower Cambrian Niutitang shales in Chongqing, in the Upper Yangtze Platform, South China, were examined using focused ion beameHe ion microscopy (FIBeHIM), nano-computerized tomography (nano-CT), and gas adsorption analysis. The results show that most pores in measured samples of the Niutitang shale are mineral matrix pores and have poor connectivity, including both intraparticle and interparticle pores. Organic matter pores in measured samples of the Niutitang shale are rare and have small diameters. In measured samples of the Longmaxi shale, OM poresdmostly macropores and large mesoporesdare the most abundant. The nano-CT results revealed that the abundance of OM pores led to good pore connectivity in the Longmaxi shale samples, whereas the prevalence of mineral matrix pores resulted in poor connectivity in the Niutitang shale samples. N2 and CO2 adsorption analyses showed that the mean value of microporeemesopore volumes in the Niutitang and Longmaxi shales samples are 0.0332 ml/g and 0.0261 ml/g, respectively. The mean values of microporesemesopores surface area in the Niutitang and Longmaxi shales samples are 33.84 m2/g and 32.46 m2/g, respectively. Thus, there is little difference between measured samples of the Longmaxi and Niutitang shales in terms of volume and surface area of microporesemesopores. The equal-vitrinite reflectance (equal-Ro) values of measured samples of the Longmaxi shale are lower than those of the Niutitang shale samples. Over-maturity (equal-Ro>3%) resulted in a reduction of the number of pores in organic matter, small pore size, and poor connectivity in measured samples of the Niutitang shale. Relatively low maturity (2%<equal-Ro<3%) resulted in better preservation of OM pores and good connectivity in measured samples of the Longmaxi shale.
